head.title: Orthodox Angels Are Aiding Women in Childbirth

hedline.hl1: Orthodox Angels Are Aiding Women in Childbirth

abstract.p: Article on work of group of 75 Orthodox Jewish women who volunteer at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, NY, as doulas, or labor coaches, for women giving birth; photo (M)

block.p: Mirrel Eissenberg, vice president of a real estate management firm, was wearing a floppy blue smock with teddy bears printed on it at the Maimonides Medical Center in Borough Park.
When she is not making property deals, she is a hand holder, a massage giver and a calming voice for women undergoing childbirth.
Mirrel Eissenberg, vice president of a real estate management firm, was wearing a floppy blue smock with teddy bears printed on it at the Maimonides Medical Center in Borough Park.
When she is not making property deals, she is a hand holder, a massage giver and a calming voice for women undergoing childbirth.
She reached into the wide pockets of her smock and pulled out the tools of her craft.

''Soothing tapes of all kinds of music, a little massager; sometimes I give that to the husbands,'' she said with a tender smile, then pulled a packet of papers from another pocket. On the pages were phrases like ''take a deep breath,'' ''push'' and ''relax,'' translated into Russian, Hindi, Polish and Spanish, then transliterated into Hebrew.

Ms. Eissenberg has a steady gaze, straight brown hair that curls neatly under her chin, and remarkably blue eyes. She is one of 75 Orthodox Jewish women who volunteer at Maimonides as doulas, or labor coaches, for women giving birth.
The doula program was created two years ago by N'Shei Cares, part of Agudath Women of America, an Orthodox Jewish women's group.

''Doula'' is a Greek word meaning handmaiden. The tradition of guiding a woman through labor is ancient, with no specific ties to Orthodox Judaism. And although Maimonides is a Jewish hospital, only 40 percent of the patients are Jews, so often the bonds forged during childbirth between the doula and the mother cross cultural barriers.
Each volunteer must take a four-day course, complete a probationary period of six months, then sign on for at least a year.
Maimonides handled more than 5,000 births last year alone, making it one of the busiest delivery rooms in the city. So hospital officials are glad to have the doulas.
''It's a busy labor room,'' said Carol Kidney, the hospital's assistant director of obstetrics and gynecology. ''And this means someone can focus primarily on the well-being of the mom.''
The organizers of the program were surprised to learn that scores of Orthodox women wanted to participate.
''It's the 'in vogue' thing to do now in our community,'' said Laya Leshkowitz of N'Shei Cares.
On a recent afternoon, as a baby's heartbeat ticked loudly on an electronic monitor in the delivery room, Ms. Eissenberg smoothed the mother's hair.

''You meet so many different people,'' she said. ''This one is saying her prayers, this one is saying another kind of prayer. Every birth is a miracle, and each of these women gives me the honor of allowing me to share it with her.''
